Author: jl777c#5810
Content: hex is 0,1,2,...9,a,b,c,d,e,f

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: only those

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 16 different hex chars

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: takes 4 bits to encode it, since 2*2*2*2 is 16

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is 2 times 2 times 2 times 2

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a byte has 8 bits

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i know it is really complex stuff, sorry

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 2 hex chars -> one byte since 4+4 equals 8

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for strings each character is represented by ASCII,some standard from the past

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is usually shown in decimal, but probably can find a hex encoding for ASCII

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: each letter -> one byte -> 2 hex chars

Author: siu - Chainmakers#3920
Content: ok

Content: 16 times 16 is 256

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what was exact 'd' oraclesdata rpc call that failed?

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: `./komodo-cli -ac_name=ORCL oraclesdata a31286453124ee7b60c838c1ee681a26ce9553b98bc8593b45fad6ffc87effe2 011`

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 011 has odd number of chars, immediately illegal

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you wanted 0101 ?

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: I wanted to put just 1 bit of binary

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: must always be even number of chars, otherwise will have a half a byte

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 1 byte is the least you can have

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is 8 bites

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 8 bits

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: Aha, so length in case of binary format means not the amount of chars but amount of bytes?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just like for 's'

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you cant write half a byte out to the blockchain

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: I thought 'd' format can parse 1 and 0 as bits somehow so possible to make boolean by 1 bit input

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: But it's operating with bytes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well it could, but ultimately one byte is the smallest amount that can be written to the blockchain, so there is no point for higher resolution

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: Great, now clear

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: So what is the most elegant way to implement boolean as data type?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the 'S' issue could be a bug as it looked ok from your description, so need the actual rpc call

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: boolean would be 00 or 01

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with 7 bits wasted

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you could pack 8 booleans into a single byte

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but that is up to the caller of the rpc to encode it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with 'd' you can put encrypted data in the hex

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: @jl777c https://docs.google.com/document/d/1z2br1U5yfZZFU67tkSloLQwoFro9HM2RW1e59LYsv6k/edit?usp=sharing my call (there is a symbol limit in Discord)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what value is that?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: plz understand little endian

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: 03e8 planned  as 1000

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: from google: https://chortle.ccsu.edu/AssemblyTutorial/Chapter-15/ass15_3.html

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: e803 is the little endian 1000, 03e8 is big endian, which is opposite of little endian

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: Thanks @jl777c ! Was clear what is it - didn't know that same logic using when declaring length

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: Have to understand better how CC working with data

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is arbitrary

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but it is simpler to always use little endian

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: instead of randomly picking little vs big for every possible case

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: bitcoin protocol has big endian and little endian depending on, well, random decisions made at the time

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so that means you need to guess which endian-ness is used for every number bigger than 1 byte

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I chose to avoid that by always using little endian

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: Oh I see

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
```oraclefeed.c now works, you do need to customize it a bit:
#define ORACLETXID "4895f631316a649e216153aee7a574bd281686265dc4e8d37597f72353facac3"
#define MYPUBKEY "02ebc786cb83de8dc3922ab83c21f3f8a2f3216940c3bf9da43ce39e2a3a882c92"
it gets the bitcoin price and writes it out
format of "L"
yo have to manually create an oracle txid, register and subscribe
then it just loops every minute. it might get an error if the prior one isnt confirmed
FSM branch
```

Also have to change assetchain ID to needed in daemon calls (AT5 at the moment). Maybe make asset chain name as definable variable as well?
